text: PA and I'm the learning technology initiatives director at the Sloan School of Management I'm part of the Executive
Education Department but I also report to the deputy Dean here at the Sloan School of Management what I'd like to do
is really talk about three things in this brief time we have together first
I'd like to explore two dimensions of education and and I'm thinking in terms of not only the classroom education
we're familiar with but also the distance education which is so prominent uh in the developments today second I'd
like to identify two key questions that I really feel are important for us to be
thinking about and addressing in the area of new technologies and education
and third I'd like to answer those questions from Stone's point of view and tell you a little bit about what we're
doing and how we're doing it finally I want toose a challenge to you and ask
you a question so let's get started when we think about these two Dimensions that I'd like to explore at first I'd like to
think about for a while the purpose of Education now if we think about the purpose of Education I'd like to invoke
Professor Russell aov's point of view he's a great thinker as a systems thinker and as a strategic planner and
he asked companies and organizations to think about not only the explicit per
purpose for which they exist but also the implicit purpose if we were to think
about education from an explicit point of view and we think about the school age or the youngster population there's
no doubt that content is very very important clearly important information
needs to be conveyed to students from people who've studied in the fields uh for a long period of time second purpose
for the explicit purpose of educational institutions is to allow students to
practice and to apply what they've learned a third explicit purpose I think we'd probably all agree is that school
environments create a situation where students can learn together where they can learn from each other so it creates
a community of Learners if you compare the explicit
purposes for adult education I think we'd agree that they're all the same again content has to be conveyed
practice or application of what is being learned is very important and thirdly it's an opportunity to learn together
and to learn from your peers now let's think about the implicit purpose of
educational institutions from the point of view of the school age or youngster
population there are really I think two implicit purposes first there's the
issue of socialization I think we all understand the importance of children growing up together and having an
opportunity to work together to become friends to learn how to resolve conflicts um and to basically interact
in a social environment a second implicit purpose for the youngster aged group is a
babysitting purpose and I think you can test that theory by asking the question if you
could educate a child by the age of six as completely as was possible and as
necessary would you choose to do it I think the answer is no as young children
come along they need a period of gestation where they in a control environment grow up now let's compare
that to the adult learner the adult learner gets tremendous value if an
educational institution is able to provide an environment where networking takes place where friendships are made
where connections are made that can be used outside and later beyond the
confines of the educational environment babysitting however is not
an issue for the adult Learner in fact it's really just the opposite the adult learner has enormous pressures on them
to to uh not take time out to learn but instead to continue working in their
work environment in the context that they are in on a day-to-day environment so I think the comparable or
the the the parallel structure for the babysitting for the younger children is that adults need time out they don't
need uh they need time out from their work environment so that they can take time to learn so I think it's very
important to keep this in mind and I'm going to be coming back to this a number of times as we talk about the
experiments that we're doing at the Salone School of Management i' like you to keep in mind the fact that these two
uh categories of purpose both the explicit and the implicit are something that we need to be responsible for in
whatever we do as designers of educational situations now I'd like to shift gears
another dimension to keep in mind throughout this discussion is the dimension of Technology we have a
dizzying array of choices that are U available to us as we think about new
ways of providing education and they fall along axis so for instance we can
think about do we want an educational experience to be facilitated or non-facilitated do we want it to be
synchronous or asynchronous do we want it be electronically delivered or do we want it to have a face-to-face component
should it be customized or and in other words uh made specific for the
particular audience or can we create something that is an off-the-shelf product that people can use in many
different environments should it be interactive or should it be one way now
these are not just academic choices there's technology that's available now
in this wonderful congruence of developments that let us do all of these things so
the challenge then comes back to the instructional designer where do you fall on these different axes what are the
choices that you're going to make technology is there you as an instructional designer have to think of
it from the point of view of fulfilling both the explicit and the implicit purposes of the educational experience
you're creating so if you think of the effect of technology on the two different
populations the Young age and the adult uh age learners for the school Age
Technology provides just extraordinary opportunities for enriching what goes on
in the classroom and I think that the conversation that we had with Bonnie bracie was perfect for that she talks so
beautifully about how can you engage students however um the teachers have
the luxury of the students remaining in the classroom because of the babysitting function they will not empty the schools
so the teacher can create this system which is multi-dimensional in its purposes and take full advantage of the
technology without jeopardizing all of the different dimensions of learning for the adult
learner the technology has the capability of freeing Us in terms of
time and space if we do that we are in great risk of jeopardizing the implicit
purposes of Education the socialization where they get to know each other and
create bonds and relationships and also that time out that time to learn you put
them into a work environment and say here go and learn and uh get back to us
when you finished this is very difficult because there's no Hiatus and the pressures of the daytoday work get very
much in the way of learning so I think these are aspects that we're going to be thinking about
and talking about and they lead me to my two key questions I think the questions that we
need to be asking ourselves in the area of management education for the adult
learner is do we face a period of disruptive technology this is the notion
that technology comes along which changes the game changes the whole way
in which you're doing business if that's the case then we as a business School
need to be thinking about in fact changing the entire way in which we proceed to do business so first question
are we facing a period of disruptive technology the second question is from a
pedagogical perspective not from a business perspective but from a pedagogical perspective do we know what
the Learning System is all about do we really know how people learn and are we
competent therefore to decompose and recompose these elements of learning so
that we are still consistent with fulfilling all the purposes both explicit and implicit of an educational
environment so those are the two questions that we're struggling with those are the two questions that Sloan
asked itself and I'd like to go on then to my third area where we really talk
about what is Sloan doing how do we answer those questions and what have we done as a result of those
answers if you ran a business School how would you answer them it's challenging so let me give you
Sloan's answers and then tell you a little bit about what we've done Sloan's answer to those two questions is to both
of them we don't know we don't know and therefore we need to do some
experiments and in those experiments we not only need to learn what there is to be learned but we also have to learn
what it is that we don't know so that was really the design for the ACT ity
that we've been pursuing since uh Dean donard convened the educational
technology task force in 1999 so let me move then to the third
area of what I'd like to talk to you about which is what has flown done and
how have we done it if we think about content as the the
first explicit purpose of Education there are a couple of things that we've done and I've mentioned these before
we've done the work with unex where we took a pre-mba package preparation
package from their uh list of available titles if you will and made it available
to our incoming MBA students this was very successful in that it was an
enrichment it gave the students an opportunity to do rust removal and self assessment on the topics that they were
going to be studying when they came onto campus so it was an opportunity for them to challenge themselves in a a
comfortable environment really preparing for the time they come on campus so this
was an experiment of using uh an online distanced product to enrich what it was
from a Content standpoint that our students would get now another content experiment that we're doing are the
knowledge updates and we spent some time talking about this this is an opportunity for us to see if we can
electronically package and deliver the results of current research in a way that's really engaging to the the person
that's that's looking at it and the challenge we've G given to ourselves is can we do that packaging in such a way
that it lays the groundwork for Community Learning coming out of people
who've who've gotten involved in looking at these Frontier topic knowledge updates so those are two experiments
we've done in the content area in the area of learning communities where we
have technology facilitating people learning from each other we've done the development of a learning platform
called slon space you're going to have an opportunity to try it so I'm looking forward to that but let me just give you
uh the the sort of overall picture of it which is that it is a student Centric portal that allows the students to
customize for themselves which portlets they want to have uh uh open when they
come to their their area and slone space and some of the portlets that are available to them are announcements
schedules class discussions class material distribution membership in the
various communities and classes in which they participate so this is an experiment
that we're doing in developing and refining our ability to provide a a
learning community platform but as you can see and and the
way I'm talking about this they really only are experiments in a couple of the
dimensions of the educational purposes that we talked about in the very beginning so now I'd like to shift to
talking about the miral Lynch Andrew Law Investments course and talk about it and
describe it to you along each one of the five Dimensions that we laid out at the
beginning when we talk about the development of Investments course
through the maril Lynch partnership effort we on the education technology task force thought of it as our
experiment in how do we create a window into the classroom so if you think of it
that that's that was the the metaphor that we used as we were thinking about the work that we were going to be doing
and we challenged ourselves to do the systems design so that we
responsibly took into account all of the dimensions that we talked about at the beginning
so thinking about this course let me take them in turn if we think about
content the Investments course uh picked up on a semester long course taught by
Professor Andrew low two secondy year MBA students very Advanced Theory taught
by a star who was a lead thinker in this area we videotaped the classes as
Professor low taught the MBA students live and then converted them to CDs and
we used the technology that allowed us to synchronize his teaching materials
beside the the window in which the video was playing it wasn't particularly High
touch uh technology we didn't allow for indexing but we did by putting it on CD
give students the ability to watch it any place any time in addition in terms
of conveying content we prepared a notebook where they would have all of the teaching materials that Professor
low used in his lecture on paper why did we do that because he teaches a very
quantitative course he speaks in the language of math and it would be very important for students to be able to
have hard copy so they could take notes on the on the paper rather than be
working very hard to copy down the equations that he used in his lectures so we captured the content and
stored it electron Ally there were 12 lectures six of which were uh added that
were optional lectures now if we think about the application or the putting of the
content into practice we put a great deal of emphasis on that we wanted to
make sure that if the students were not going to be given the time out to learn
we needed to provide a vehicle where they could take advantage of learning in their work context to actually put the
theory into practice in order to do that we built a project groups were assigned
and these students came from all over the world so we made a great effort in in the selection of the student groups
that we put together and we set up the the project in three phases the first
phase required them to identify a customer that was not well served by
maril Lynch or perhaps a new customer and to profile those customers in turn
terms of their risk and investment preferences part two was that they had
to design a new product to service that maril Lynch had never offered before that was specifically appropriate to
meet the needs of this this customer group and third they were required to
put together an implementation plan where they did the cost benefit analysis to Mara Lynch for offering this new
product or service these were very sophisticated projects that were developed they shared
their projects with each other as they were preparing them in fact we had an interesting situation where the project
of one group of students was in fact a great solution for the product of
another uh group of students um and then in the end of the course they presented their projects not only to Professor low
but also to senior managers at Merl Lynch this is how we address that that
uh purpose of Education to give students an opportunity to apply and practice what they've learned so we've talked
about content application practice third explicit uh purpose of an educational
situation was to provide a learning community this we did um we set up a
number of vehicles for peer-to-peer exchange and peer-to expert
exchange with each lecture we put together pre-lecture questions and
post-lecture questions that the students required to answer and they used that
learning community space that I told you about before Sloan space on Sloan space were discussion
groups for each one of the lectures and as students posted their pre- and post questions they went directly to the
discussion space about that particular lecture they were accompanied in this
dialogue by the TA who came from Sloan who was a subject matter expert and the
learning director who came from Mara Lynch who was responsible for managing
the lives of the students and and the pressures on them so both the TA and the
learning director got involved in the discussions by uh overseeing the
activity intervening when help was needed either because people were becoming overwhelmed or were dropping by
the wayside or because they were confused and they needed some help from a Content standpoint in fact partway through would
tell you the story we actually changed the assignment we were dissatisfied with the dialogue that was taking place and
we asked students to answer one question and then comment on the response of
another student so this this is one of the things that we changed Midway through so understand we didn't get it
right first off we were experimenting throughout the the project another venue for Community
Learning we set up to have office hours synchronous office hours with the
students and the professor where uh using a text chat room uh text based
chat room they were able to communicate with Professor low to ask questions and to exchange views and to have his
feedback on their projects so we devised a number of different ways for them to
learn from each other and from the experts so those are really the three explicit purposes that we identified at
the beginning now let me switch to the implicit purposes of socialization and
timeout for socialization we designed the course so that at the beginning of the course and
at the end of the course the students were brought literally from all over the world to New York and they spent a day
uh with Professor low and with each other during the lunch of the first day
their project groups were assigned seatings so we asked them to sit together over lunch and begin to develop
the Rapport get to know each other because after that first day all they would be doing is communicating through
technological means um we um asked them to identify
themselves and identify themselves not only in terms of the work that they were
doing but the capabilities that they might bring to the group as a whole from a socialization standpoint
again at the end of the course after the final day we had a very nice graduation
party which was attended by Professor Low by the head of the global debt
Market group and Senior membership uh senior sponsors from the top management
team very not fancy but having a chance to have a beer together sitting down
down around the table be presented with graduation certificates be congratulated individually it was a very very
important part of cementing the Friendship bonds that it started at the beginning of this 12we course and that
would take them going forward an interesting piece of data is that the students reported that one of the
primary values they got out of the course was the opportunity to learn uh get to know people throughout the
company that it would have taken them years to uh get to know on their own
that was how we addressed the socialization issue now how did we address the timeout what we did with
this course because we made it time and space dependent was we in fact violated
the timeout rule we plunged them into this intense learning experience in the
context of their own work um let me tell you the way we solve that problem we solved it by focusing a
great deal on motivating the students why because these are students that
don't know how to spell time out they're very aggressive type A people who just
um simply made two extra hours out of their 24-hour day so it was very
important that we keep their motivation high so that they would not in the compression of time and the requirements
of their very high stress jobs uh collapse under the weight how did we do
this we started we had the Good Fortune of starting with the very top person in
the global debt Market group feeling this was a very important initiative within the within his organization
why did he feel that way first of all he wanted to embed in his upand cominging
um High potentials the the use and application of really Advanced
investment Theory so he wanted to imw them with a new way of thinking about
how they did business secondly he was very interested in treating them as a group to a a
particularly um significant communication from him and from
management that they were a valued part of the team the students that were were
brought into this course were in that interesting Gap in the professions where
they have been with the company for a couple of years but it will probably be four more years before they're
considered for the big leap for the big uh advancement High potentials during
this period of time are very likely to leave and what uh the head of the global
debt Market group wanted to do was send a signal that these people were high potentials were recognized as such and
that meil Lynch was willing to invest in them in order to increase the
retention so we had the head of the group having it a very high priority he
then asked his direct reports to work with their direct reports to nominate
the correct people 70 people were identified 30 were selected for the
course with five alternates so you can see right away that these students knew that they were being selected as a very
honored pool throughout the course the people who had nominated the students were
encouraged to be good sponsors and to to take an interest in their studies we had
uh senior Executives from the group sponsoring the group projects might or
might not have been somebody who uh had sponsored a student but it was somebody
who was very interested in the business that project might be integrated into
and finally we had when the project was presented not only the sponsors but also
the business heads that would be the top two layers of the organization listen to
the projects evaluate them and then feedback whether or not they would be
taking them forward and putting them into practice this kept the students highly
motivated as you can imagine this was a degree of exposure that was very very unusual for people at their age and
stage and I think it was successful in terms of creating motivation as a way to
simulate the time out that was not allowed to them in the design of the course so I've gone through all these uh
Dimensions because I wanted to make sure that you could understand that when you're creating an entire course or an
entire educational engagement it's very important to think about both the
explicit and the implicit purposes and it's at your peril that you ignore any
one of these Dimensions it is a system and the there are interdependencies
among the system if you don't account for all of them in your design uh the system may not work that gives you a
little bit of an of an exposure to what we've done so let me just tell you what
we're doing next we're going to take what we've learned and run the course
again at Mara Lynch and then we want to take it further and take what we've learned and see if we can be developing
additional educational experiences with new components um and and see if this
isn't a a way that we can have have learned how to do education taking
advantage of tech technology and not having technology get in the way of the ultimate learning experience of the
student so this really wraps up uh the material that I'd like to cover in this
this brief conversation with you and I'd like to lead you with a challenge and a
question the challenge is for the work that you're going to be doing and the class time we'll spend together that
what we're talking about is not about creating fancy uh technologically
composed content it's not about making the material relevant and easy to apply
and giving opportunities to do that it's not about creating interaction and
Community it's not about providing operate uh opportunities for people to
get to know each other and to build friendships and it's not about giving
either uh time out or motivation to keep people engaged the challeng is it's
about all of them it's about all of them so as you think about uh Professor
miwa's class when he talks about education and media and the
marketplace I'd like to suggest that your jobs our jobs are to figure out as
we produce anything and work on anything we need to put in the hands of
Educators a a comprehensive product a product that helps teachers know not
only how to convey content in a new way or create U interaction among your
students in a new way but how does it fit into the other dimensions of the educational
experience what I'd like to at least introduce to you is the exercise that
we're going to be doing together homework will be posted I'll be giving you a write up about it what I'm going
to be asking you to do is help me develop ways to improve the Andrew low
course and the dimension that we're going to be focusing on is the dimension of building a learning community this is
an area we've identified for ourselves we need need to do a better job with and I think that you're a good brain trust
that uh will be good opportunity for us to tap so I'm going to be asking you to
experience not only the lecture but also the Learning Community I'm going to be asking you to read the evaluation that
that we did of our own work I'm going to be asking you to find resources that
help inform your opinions about how we can do a better job at building a learning community and then I'm going to
ask you to begin to design an approach give me some recommendations that we can take forward and put into the new
courses that we're going to be developing look forward to working with you on this I appreciate the time that
you spent uh watching this video if you have any feedback on this video as a way
of communicating to you uh from me to you I'd very much appreciate hearing from you look forward to seeing you at
the next class
